text:
Hi friends :wave::skin-tone-5: :wave::skin-tone-5:

I started working with legal-tech scale-up a few months ago and since then my solo role has turned into a team lead role which is equal parts exciting and equal parts terrifying! :sweat_smile:

My team now comprises of a *Marketing Coordinator* and a *Content Associate* and both of them are lawyers and subject matter expert but do not have enough marketing experience, which is where I come in. 

I’ve not had a solid team lead experience until now except for handling external freelancers and managing team on a dotted line. So I’m hoping this group can guide me a bit here:

What should the division of duties look like here? For now the MC writes blogs, schedules and writes social media posts, a few products posts and helps with day to day admin + has slightly better understanding of SEO at this time. 

The MA will be joining soon and while I want to groom her for SEO I’d like to have clear distinction between the tasks for these two. 

What do you suggest is the right way of going about this? I’ll appreciate any inputs. 

Tagging a few of my favourite content people here, but jump on and help this girl out <@U010JU2GTND> <@U017WRJTKF1> <@URAV154AV> <@UJ7RT1J1X>

TIA :raised_hands::skin-tone-5::boom:

elements.text: Hi friends
I started working with legal-tech scale-up a few months ago and since then my solo role has turned into a team lead role which is equal parts exciting and equal parts terrifying!
My team now comprises of a
Marketing Coordinator
and a
Content Associate

and both of them are lawyers and subject matter expert but do not have enough marketing experience, which is where I come in. 

I’ve not had a solid team lead experience until now except for handling external freelancers and managing team on a dotted line. So I’m hoping this group can guide me a bit here:

What should the division of duties look like here? For now the MC writes blogs, schedules and writes social media posts, a few products posts and helps with day to day admin + has slightly better understanding of SEO at this time. 

The MA will be joining soon and while I want to groom her for SEO I’d like to have clear distinction between the tasks for these two. 

What do you suggest is the right way of going about this? I’ll appreciate any inputs. 

Tagging a few of my favourite content people here, but jump on and help this girl out
TIA

text:
Congrats on the new role!

Some people disagree, but I don't think it's that important to rigidly define duties up front. Rather, I think it's *really* important to understand the overall picture of tasks facing your team.

That lets you pair tasks more closely with each person's strengths/expertise  (hard to do up front, because people are different!) — and if you approach it intentionally you'll have a clear delineation of who does what before too long.

As for people working on distinct things, that's fine if that's what your org needs, but it's also not a requirement. I've had writers on a team who largely did the same type of work, and I've had teams where everyone did something completely different.

This last bit depends on the context somewhat, but the final thing I'd say is that I generally want to push decision making as far down the hierarchy as possible. If these people don't have much marketing background yet that may not be possible yet, but I'd have it in the back of your mind that you want to be making them more self-sufficient and able to make bigger decisions over time

text:
Hey there! My team is already remote, with a day or two a week in-office IRL. However, we're shifting to a remote-only team in January. We've been looking into virtual office space options for having efficient, collaborative communication while we're all online, but I haven't used something like this before and don't want to spend the money on it if it's not worth the hassle.

For context, our team is current 4 in-house folks and is likely to grow by at least a couple of people in 2022. 

My two questions are:

1. What has been your experience using a virtual coworking platform? Effective? Waste of time/resources? Might as well just use Slack?
2. If you had a good experience, which platform do you recommend?
TIA!

elements.text: Hey there! My team is already remote, with a day or two a week in-office IRL. However, we're shifting to a remote-only team in January. We've been looking into virtual office space options for having efficient, collaborative communication while we're all online, but I haven't used something like this before and don't want to spend the money on it if it's not worth the hassle.

For context, our team is current 4 in-house folks and is likely to grow by at least a couple of people in 2022. 

My two questions are:
What has been your experience using a virtual coworking platform? Effective? Waste of time/resources? Might as well just use Slack?
If you had a good experience, which platform do you recommend?
TIA!

text:
My two cents from experience with a virtual office at my previous company: It was a total waste of time and resources.

We used Sococo and the CEO spent _hours_ building a replica of the actual office for people to virtually hang out in. Of course, no one ever did and the tool quickly became underutilized. Keeping Sococo running all day in the background was also a huge RAM and battery drain.

If you do decide to implement, make sure you have some solid processes in place. A pit we fell into was Zoom links were shared in Sococo rooms and of course, no one really knew where the link was, meetings ran late, and it was generally quite chaotic.

I hope that was somewhat useful!

text:
I agree with Claire, they don't work. We used Tandem and it was almost never used.

I would recommend doing a few virtual meetups every week and use the Slack huddle more often - acts like a coffee chat when you move around a real office and stumble upon another co-worker.
